factoid: The girl smiled.
The girl took it.
Nesvítski kept his eyes on the women until they had passed.
Nesvítski was like the rest of the men on the bridge.
The men on the bridge kept their eyes on the women until they had passed.
The same stream of soldiers followed the women.
The soldiers talked in the same kind of talk.
All stopped.
The horses of a convoy wagon became restive at the end of the bridge.
The whole crowd had to wait.
The soldiers asked, "And why are they stopping?"
The soldiers said, "There’s no proper order!"
The soldiers asked, "Where are you shoving to?"
The soldiers said, "Devil take you!"
The soldiers said, "Can’t you wait?"
The soldiers said, "It’ll be worse if he fires the bridge."
The soldiers said, "See, here’s an officer jammed in too."
Different voices were saying in the crowd.
The men looked at one another.
All pressed toward the exit from the bridge.
Nesvítski looked down at the waters of the Enns under the bridge.
Nesvítski suddenly heard a new sound.
The sound was of something swiftly approaching.
The sound was of something big.
The sound splashed into the water.
A soldier near by said, "Just see where it carries to!"
The soldier looked round at the sound.
Another soldier said, "Encouraging us to get along quicker," uneasily.
The crowd moved on again.
Nesvítski realized that the sound was a cannon ball.
Nesvítski said, "Hey, Cossack, my horse!"
Nesvítski said, "Now, then, you there! get out of the way!"
Nesvítski said, "Make way!"
Nesvítski managed to get to his horse with great difficulty.
Nesvítski shouted continually as he moved on.
The soldiers squeezed themselves to make way for Nesvítski.
The soldiers pressed on Nesvítski again so that they jammed his leg.
Those nearest Nesvítski were not to blame because they were pressed still harder from behind.
A hoarse voice from behind Nesvítski said, "Nesvítski, Nesvítski! you numskull!"
Nesvítski looked round and saw Váska Denísov.
Váska Denísov was some fifteen paces away from Nesvítski.
Váska Denísov was separated by the living mass of moving infantry.
Váska Denísov was red and shaggy.
Váska Denísov had his cap on the back of his black head.
Váska Denísov had a cloak hanging jauntily over his shoulder.
Váska Denísov shouted, "Tell these devils, these fiends, to let me pass!"
Váska Denísov shouted in a fit of rage.
Váska Denísov had coal-black eyes with bloodshot whites glittering and rolling.
Váska Denísov waved his sheathed saber in a small bare hand.
The hand was red as Váska Denísov’s face.
Nesvítski replied joyfully, "Ah, Váska!"
Nesvítski said, "What’s up with you?"
Denísov shouted, "The squadwon can’t pass."
Denísov showed his white teeth fiercely.
Denísov spurred his black thoroughbred Arab.
The black thoroughbred Arab twitched its ears as the bayonets touched it.
The black thoroughbred Arab snorted.
The black thoroughbred Arab spurting white foam from its bit.
The black thoroughbred Arab tramped the planks of the bridge with its hoofs.
The black thoroughbred Arab was apparently ready to jump over the railings if its rider let.
Denísov shouted, "What is this?"
Denísov shouted, "They’re like sheep!"
Denísov shouted, "Just like sheep!"
Denísov shouted, "Out of the way!"
Denísov shouted, "Let us pass!"
Denísov shouted, "Stop there, you devil with the cart!"
Denísov shouted, "I’ll hack you with my saber!"
Denísov drew his saber from its scabbard.
Denísov flourished his saber.
The soldiers crowded against one another with terrified faces.
Denísov joined Nesvítski.
Nesvítski asked, "How’s it you’re not drunk today?" when Denísov had ridden up to him.
Denísov answered, "They don’t even give one time to dwink!"
Denísov said, "They keep dwagging the wegiment to and fwo all day."
Denísov said, "If they mean to fight, let’s fight."
Denísov said, "But the devil knows what this is."
Nesvítski said, "What a dandy you are today!"
Nesvítski looked at Denísov’s new cloak and saddlecloth.
Denísov smiled.
Denísov took out a handkerchief from his sabretache.
The handkerchief diffused a smell of perfume.
Denísov put the handkerchief to Nesvítski’s nose.
Denísov said, "Of course."
Denísov said, "I’m going into action!"
Denísov said, "I’ve shaved."
Denísov said, "I’ve brushed my teeth."
Denísov said, "I’ve scented myself."
The imposing figure of Nesvítski was followed by his Cossack.
Denísov was determined.
Denísov flourished his sword.
Denísov shouted frantically.
Their combined effect allowed them to squeeze through to the farther side of the bridge.
They stopped the infantry.
Beside the bridge, Nesvítski found the colonel.
Nesvítski had to deliver an order to the colonel.
Nesvítski delivered the order to the colonel.
Nesvítski rode back.
